command: bash -lc 'MAC="\x00\x11\x22\x33\x44\x55"; { printf "\xff%.0s" {1..6}; for i in {1..16}; do printf "$MAC"; done; } | nc -u -b -w1 255.255.255.255 9'
explanation: Builds a Wake-on-LAN magic packet in pure Bash (6x FF + 16x MAC) and broadcasts it via UDP/9 to wake the target system, enabling functionality for follow-on access. Root not strictly required to send a broadcast UDP, but some environments restrict broadcast; running as root aligns with raw socket and network constraints. Detection: log and alert on WoL-pattern UDP frames, especially if originating from servers that don't normally perform WoL.
rationale_steps: Assemble the exact WoL frame with FF header and repeated MAC.
Send via UDP broadcast to the standard WoL port 9.
Wakes sleeping devices to re-enable reachable services.
Use Bash and netcat; no exotic tooling.
Detection: DPI signature for WoL; anomaly detection for broadcast spikes and out-of-profile senders.
